> @merlimat what's the motivation for this? This is the first thing to introduce partitions in the client API.

Motivation is to create consumers (and more typically readers) on the specific partitions. 

There are multiple reasons for this to be useful: 
 * Reader can only be created on 1 partition. When reading from a partitioned topic, application will have to know upfront the number of partitions
 * There is a REST API for that, though inconvenient from client lib
 * The other often suggested route was to downcast `PulsarClient` to `PulsarClientImpl` and call https://github.com/apache/pulsar/blob/c2977bef98a2189f0aef70a97c76240bfa24a191/pulsar-client/src/main/java/org/apache/pulsar/client/impl/PulsarClientImpl.java#L791 though we should have an "official" way to do this

In general, if you want to use some custom logic to assign consumers/readers to partitions, you need to known the number of partitions and their names (the name is with `-partition-N`, though I believe it's better to provide the list rather than just then number).

I see the same problem in 2.2.0. It seems like once this happens, the topic effectively becomes unusable with no way to write messages to it (even after deleting and recreating the entire tenant). Are there any workarounds?

run integration tests

If I understand well, if I have a shared subscription and need to failover to the backup cluster, I can't know which messages had been acked for this subscription, is that correct ? With a retry/dead letter queue strategy, the rollback needed could be more than 10 minutes and the amount of messages that would be duplicated could be quite huge... And I guess it would reset the retry counter (not the biggest issue, we had a full cluster crash after all...)
Will "replicated subscription" solve this issue ? Do you have a planned date for this feature ? How can we help ?

rerun java8 tests
for  org.apache.pulsar.functions.worker.PulsarWorkerAssignmentTest.testFunctionAssignmentsWithRestart
@rdhabalia Could this solved with the per-subscription auth mechanism which is already available?

>  per-subscription auth mechanism which is already available?

@merlimat I didn't see a placeholder which keeps map of authorized roles for a given subscription so, broker can authorize admin-api request. also, I am not exactly aware about per-sub auth, can you please point me the PR or change.
@rdhabalia  https://github.com/apache/pulsar/pull/899

Oh.. no, that will not help because in our useacase, recently many of the existing subscribers are reaching out to system-admin to execute subscription admin-api (eg: skip-all, skip, reset-cursor) due to multiple reasons (eg: backlog quota exceeded, reseting cursor with retention enable, etc..). So, in that case it's hard to handle multiple requests from subscribers so, it's better to let subscriber handle those admin-api.

#899 restricts subscription-name creation with the role-name prefix but it will not address authorization of existing subscription name which doesn't have role-name prefix.

> #899 restricts subscription-name creation with the role-name prefix but it will not address authorization of existing subscription name which doesn't have role-name prefix.

My only concern is to end up with 2 ways to do (almost) the same thing, which might be confusing to users.
Isn't it possible to give permissions to these subscriptions individually (with the existing solution and without changing subscription names) ?

> Isn't it possible to give permissions to these subscriptions individually

Umm.. #899 doesn't store authorized subscriber role-names. it authorizes request based on the sub-name (eg. `myRoleName-mysub`). so, if sub-auth mode is enabled then sub-name has to start with `myRoleName` so, user with `myRoleName` role is authorized for `mysub`. 
But existing subscription `mysub` can't be accessed by `myRoleName` because it doesn't start with role-name. 
So, I am not sure how can we use this solution in a straight forward way to address above issue. Can you please let me know if I am missing anything here.
Also need to remove from `distribution/server/src/assemble/bin.xml`
@merlimat thanks for pointing that out.  I have removed that as well
rerun java8 tests
@merlimat addressed it.

@merlimat I think #899 can be only useful to avoid conflicting name because for authorization it enforces role name prefix and it has to be part of sub-name and that is something not feasible. 
So, for user, `sub-auth-mode` feature can be used to avoid conflicting name and sub-auth policies required for actual authorization. ??

> Yes, next I wanted to integrate this policy with consumer authorization so, at that time we can deprecate sub-prefix-mode and utilize per-sub authorization mechanism. I will try to address it in next PR.

I almost agree with deprecating the sub prefix mode and introducing per-subscription auth mode.

Let me confirm:
> Whoever has "consume" access on any of these, will be able to consume and perform admin related operations on that topic/subscription.

If we grant `*` on consume role, can any consumer subscribe regardless of per-subscription role?
rerun integration tests

> If we grant * on consume role, can any consumer subscribe regardless of per-subscription role?

right now, it's not supporting wild-card char such as `*` but 
- consumer can subscribe to any subscription if consumer's principal/role is authorized at namespace-level (`consume`) or per-topic (`consume`).
- however, if per-subscription auth is configured for a specific subscription-name then consumer's `principal/role` has to be authorized role as per `per-subscription` to connect to that specific subscription. so, in `pre-fix sub` usecase, user can grant access to set of roles for a specific subscription and only those roles can access the subscription. so, we can avoid sub-name conflict.

> however, if per-subscription auth is configured for a specific subscription-name then consumer's principal/role has to be authorized role as per per-subscription to connect to that specific subscription. 

OK, thanks.

@foreversunyao we kept the version as 2.9.7 in root/pom.xml for a reason (see https://github.com/apache/pulsar/pull/2978#discussion_r233182095)

I actually tried building from latest master, I can't reproduce your problem. The error you encountered seems indicating you have a bad 2.9.7 version cached locally. I would suggest you removing that from your local repository (`rm -r /Users/haoli/.m2/repository/com/fasterxml/jackson/core/jackson-core/2.9.7) and rebuild.

A conan.io support would make all this much simpler

@nha Do you mean you have some JSON data in a string and want to publish that with schema associated? There is `Schema.AUTO_PRODUCE_BYTES()` that will do that, although it only works if the topic has already a schema associated.
rerun integration tests
rerun java8 tests
rerun integration tests

After discussion, the way to do what I want is to:

- 1 - create a schemaless topic
- 2 - use the `POST /admin/v2/schemas/:tenant/:namespace/:topic/schema` endpoint to set a schema straight after that ( http://pulsar.apache.org/docs/en/admin-api-schemas/#pulsar-admin )
- 3 - use `AUTO_PRODUCE_BYTES` as mentioned above
The suspicion is that this might be due to the scenario described in https://github.com/netty/netty/issues/8563
